dc:description:
*DNAAF2* was first described as a primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD)-causing gene in 2008 (Omran et al. 2008, PMID: 19052621). The specific disease entity, primary ciliary dyskinesia 10 (MONDO:0012918, OMIM:612518), is one of at least 45 different primary ciliary dyskinesias distinguished by a single monogenic cause. Some of the most common patient phenotypes are: bronchiectasis, recurrent pneumonia, chronic sinusitis, chronic otitis media, situs inversus totalis, male or female infertility, and immotile cilia. Absent or defective outer dynein arms (ODAs) and inner dynein arms (IDAs) have been observed in respiratory cilia and spermatozoa. The patients evaluated in this curation have onset as early as at birth.

This curation includes six variants (three missense, two frameshift and one nonsense) that have been reported in five probands in three publications (PMIDs: 32638265,19052621, 34785929). Four of the probands were homozygous, with two confirmed to have consanguineous parents, while one proband was compound heterozygous with confirmation of carrier status in the parents.

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by multiple forms of experimental evidence, including the biochemical function of the gene product, its protein interactions and expression pattern, and animal models (PMIDs: 32638265, 31107948, 19052621, 33635866, 23525783, 23715323, 29358401). *DNAAF2* encodes a factor involved in preassembly of dynein arm complexes, and physically interacts with SPAG1 and HEATR2/DNAAF5, two other dynein assembly factors known to harbor variants causing PCD (PMID: 29358401). High levels of expression of *DNAAF2* were found in multiciliated human tissues associated with PCD, particularly the fallopian tubes, lungs, and testes (PMID: 23715323, PMID:31107948). A *Dnaaf2* knockout mouse model showed abnormal development with reversed laterality (e.g. heart looping), demonstrating that DNAAF2 function is necessary for the establishment of correct left–right patterning of abdominal organs during embryo formation (PMID: 31107948). A second mouse model showed situs inversus totalis, abnormal ciliary motility, and absent inner and outer dynein arms, as well as hydrocephalus (PMID: 23525783). A Medaka fish model showed an organ laterality defect, male infertility, abnormal ciliary motility, and absent ODAs and IDAs (PMID: 19052621). A transformation-generated mutant in *pf13*, the *Chlamydomonas* orthologue of *DNAAF2*, showed absent inner and outer dynein arms and static flagella, which could be rescued by wild-type gene.

In conclusion, *DNAAF2* is definitively associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia 10. This classification has been clearly demonstrated and confirmed through both experimental and genetic evidence and has been upheld over time without the emergence of conflicting evidence. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on February 8th, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to homozygosity, consanguinity and lack of through testing methods.

In Western blots of cell lysates from control respiratory cells, an anti-KTU antibody detects a specific band at ~95kDa, compatible with the size of the predicted 837 amino acid KTU protein encoded by all three exons (Fig. 2c).

evidence.rdfs:label: OP-234 II1
evidence.detectionMethod: "We correlated the findings of the HVMA with a diverse set of genetic PCD variants using Sisson-Ammons Video Analysis (SAVA)."
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Consanguineous family. The parents were heterozygous for the detected mutations.

In Western blots of cell lysates from control respiratory cells, an anti-KTU antibody detects a specific band at ~95kDa, compatible with the size of the predicted 837 amino acid KTU protein encoded by all three exons (Fig. 2c).

evidence.dc:description: The mutations in the DNAAF2 gene may be loss-of-function mutations and closely associated with the pre-assembly of dynein arm complexes, which provide energy for the cilia. As expected, our data showed defects in the ODAs (DNAH5 and DNAH9) and IDAs (DNALI1) in the respiratory cilia and spermatozoa obtained from the proband (Figs. ​(Figs.4 and ​and 5). This specific defect, which results from the dysfunctional DNAAF2 protein or the lack of DNNAF2 protein synergy in the spermatozoa, may cause an abnormal ODA and IDA assembly and the complete immotility of the sperm cells, thereby demonstrating the essential role played by DNAAF2 in axonemal assembly (Fig. 6b and c).

The mutations in the DNAAF2 gene may be loss-of-function mutations and closely associated with the pre-assembly of dynein arm complexes, which provide energy for the cilia. As expected, our data showed defects in the ODAs (DNAH5 and DNAH9) and IDAs (DNALI1) in the respiratory cilia and spermatozoa obtained from the proband (Figs. ​(Figs.4 and ​and 5). This specific defect, which results from the dysfunctional DNAAF2 protein or the lack of DNNAF2 protein synergy in the spermatozoa, may cause an abnormal ODA and IDA assembly and the complete immotility of the sperm cells, thereby demonstrating the essential role played by DNAAF2 in axonemal assembly (Fig. 6b and c).

evidence.rdfs:label: III:1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband (III:1) exhibited typical PCD-related clinical symptoms, including chronic otitis media, and recurrent pneumonia since birth (Table 1). The computed tomography examination of the proband showed chronic ethmoid and maxillary sinusitis, ring-shaped or ductal opacities throughout both lungs, bilateral lung bronchiectasis, and situs inversus totalis in the heart, liver, and colon (Supplementary Fig. 1)

Both mutations were present in the proband (III:1), and each of his parents was an unaffected carrier of one of the mutations. The proband’s father carried the mutation c.156C>A, while the proband’s mother carried the mutation c.26C>A (Table ​(Table1).1). The other unaffected family members carried either none or just one of the two mutations (Table 1).

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to consanguinity and homozygosity.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband 2
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger DNA sequencing chromatogram. A high-performance homozygosity mapping tool and next-generation sequencing data of the proband was performed to map the homozygous gene distribution.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband has a consanguineous family (Figure 1B). HRCT revealed diffuse bronchiectasis. The nasal NO output level was 2.4 nL/min (Table 1).

Inbreeding coefficient: 1/16. Nasal NO (nL/min): 2.4.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Homozygosity mapping confirmed the homozygous region in chromosome 14 contains the variants of DNAAF2 in the proband (Figure 3).

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to homozygosity, consanguinity and lack of through testing methods. Upscored for functional evidence.

In Western blots of cell lysates from control respiratory cells, an anti-KTU antibody detects a specific band at ~95kDa, compatible with the size of the predicted 837 amino acid KTU protein encoded by all three exons (Fig. 2c). In contrast, no specific band was detected for the affected children of family OP-146, confirming a loss-of-function mutation in the KTU gene (Fig. 2c).

evidence.rdfs:label: OP-146-II-3
evidence.detectionMethod: "We correlated the findings of the HVMA with a diverse set of genetic PCD variants using Sisson-Ammons Video Analysis (SAVA)."
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Consanguineous family. The parents were heterozygous for the detected mutations and, within the family, the mutation clearly co-segregated with the disease status.

In Western blots of cell lysates from control respiratory cells, an anti-KTU antibody detects a specific band at ~95kDa, compatible with the size of the predicted 837 amino acid KTU protein encoded by all three exons (Fig. 2c). In contrast, no specific band was detected for the affected children of family OP-146, confirming a loss-of-function mutation in the KTU gene (Fig. 2c).

evidence.dc:description: Default score for missense variant.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband 1
evidence.detectionMethod:
CaseMethod1: Immunofluorescence.

CaseMethod2: High-speed microscopy analysis.

CaseGenotypingMethod: Sanger sequencing chromatogram. A high-performance homozygosity mapping tool and next-generation sequencing data of the proband was performed to map the homozygous gene distribution.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband has a consanguineous family (Figure 1A). She denied any history of asthma, immunodeficiency, measles, tuberculosis, etc. Her family members had no similar symptoms or history of respiratory disease.

High-resolution CT (HRCT) revealed diffuse bronchiectasis and situs inversus and upright radiograph indicated a Cobb’s angle of 13.5° (Figure 2A–C). Her nasal NO output level was 25.2 nL/min (Table 1). She was marked "yes" for having a "Smell problem". No hearing problems.

Inbreeding coefficient: 1/16. FEV1% prediction: 76%. FEV1/FVC:72%. Cobb’s angle: 13.5°. Nasal NO (nL/min): 25.2.

Segregation of the variant DNAAF2, c.491T>C, p.(Leu164Pro) in two healthy sisters of proband 1 was also validated by Sanger sequencing (Supplementary Figure 1). Homozygosity mapping confirmed the homozygous region in chromosome 14 contains the variants of DNAAF2 in the proband (Figure 3). Immunofluorescence of nasal ciliated cells of the proband revealed the absence of ODA (Figure 4). High-speed microscopy showed that the most of the nasal cilia are static in the proband compared with the normal control (Supplementary Video 1 and Supplementary Video 2).

evidence.dc:description: This was downscored because the model is in the embryonic stage and is not displaying  many phenotypes.
The embryonic mice are displaying right-left laterality defects which are similar to the human phenotype of situs inversus totalis. Figure 5.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cheong 2019 et al

evidence.dc:description: Downscored because the fish lacks the ability to display respiratory phenotypes

The phenotypes presented by the medaka showed a lot of similarities to the ones displayed by the human probands. For example, the medaka phenotype of situs inversus totalis matches with the human phenotype of situs inversus totalis. The medeka phenotype of male infertility matches with the human phenotypes of female and male infertility. While the medeka had immotile ciliopathy and absent ODA/IDA, the humans had immotile cilia and cilia with ODA/IDA defects.
evidence.rdfs:label: Omran et al. 2008 Medaka

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to the model being unable to display the respiratory phenotypes like humans

One of the recurring phenotypes of PCD in human patients is ODA and IDA defects. This experiment with Chlamydomonas demonstrates loss of motility (paralyzed flagella) as well as recurrence of the partial ODA and IDA loss.
evidence.rdfs:label: Omran et al. 2008 Chlamydomonas

evidence.dc:description: Both the model organism and the humans had situs inversus totalis. The mouse model had hydrocephalus which is similar to the human phenotypes of recurrent pneumonia and bronchiectasis due to the inflammation/build up of fluids. Additionally, the mouse models phenotypes of abnormal ciliary motility and absent inner and outer dynein arms matches with the human phenotypes of immotile sperm, male infertility and female infertility.
evidence.rdfs:label: Matsuo et al. 2013

evidence.dc:description: Because the model cannot display multiciliary phenotypes.
Gene identity was confirmed by rescuing the mutant phenotype with wild-type genomic clones (Supplementary Table S5), and by the absence of the gene product in mutant cells (Supplementary Fig. S4f).
evidence.rdfs:label: Omran et al. 2008

evidence.dc:description: This was scored at 0 due to the description of laterality which led to the evidence being re-categorized as a mouse model instead

DNAAF2 -/- embryos were found to have abnormal formation with certain elements forming on the right as opposed to the typical left lateral side. These observations indicate that Dnaaf2 function is required for proper establishment of left–right patterning during embryogenesis possibly because of abnormal node function.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cheong 2019 et al

evidence.dc:description: This was downscored to 0 because there wasn’t an appropriate figure available to cite as evidence.
The deletion of DNAAF2 affected the formation of cilia, movement and length which is consistent with PCD phenotypes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Aprea et al. 2021

evidence.dc:description: This was scored at 0 because while the wild-type Dnaaf2 has a very specific localization pattern in the mouse embryo, it is unknown if the "lateral plate mesoderm", "neural tube", and "gut tube" develop into PCD-related tissues like the lungs or reproductive areas.

Dnaaf2 mRNA is present specifically in the epiblast at E6.5 and in all newly specified embryonic lineages at E7.5 but is conspicuously absent from all extraembryonic lineages, even those that are primitive streak derived including the allantois and yolk sac mesoderm (Fig. 1C and D). Importantly, Dnaaf2 is expressed in the embryonic node at E7.5. In late gastrulation and organogenesis stage embryos, Dnaaf2 expression becomes further restricted to the lateral plate mesoderm, the neural tube, gut tube and first branchial arch (Fig. 1E and F). As expected, Dnaaf2 signal was completely absent in Dnaaf2−/− embryos (Fig. 1G) confirming the specificity of the ISH expression patterns observed.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cheong 2019 et al

evidence.dc:description: Uncertainty due to area of localization and how it affects cilia formation and motility. Also, did not want to double count data.
The loss of function mutations caused by the lack of DNAAF2 affected ODA and IDA assembly and cilia formation which is consistent with PCD phenotypes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Sun et al. 2020

evidence.dc:description: SPAG1 has a definitive gene-disease relationship with PCD. DNAAF5 has not yet been curated yet.
evidence.rdfs:label: Horani, et al. 2019

evidence.dc:description: PMID: 23715323. Variant was expressed primarily in fallopian tubes, lungs, Cells - Cultured fibroblasts and testis. Additionally, in paper PMID: 31107948, the experiment results are consistent with the data in the GTEX.
evidence.rdfs:label: Genet 2015

evidence.dc:description: Since Dnaaf2 is associated with proper cilia function, it is not surprising that the gene is expressed in multiciliated tissues including brain, kidney, liver, lung, ovary, oviduct, spleen and testis (Fig. 1A).
evidence.rdfs:label: Cheong 2019 et al
